metadata.titleEn: Monitoring Data Set of Body Weights of Traditional Grazing Yaks in Qinghai Pastoral Area (2018)
metadata.description:
The content of this data set is the measurements of body weight and body size (body height, body length, chest circumference, tube circumference) of 11 representative yak populations in Qinghai pastoral area at 2018. All the metadata comes from the work of body weight monitoring of yaks in Qinghai pastoral area at 2018, by the Northwest Institute of Plateau Biology, Chinese Academy of Sciences and Qinghai Academy of Animal Husbandry and Veterinary Sciences. The data set is named by “Monitoring Data Set of Body Weights of Traditional Grazing Yaks in Qinghai Pastoral Area (2018)”, consisting of 11 worksheets. The names and contents of worksheets are as follows:
1. Haiyan-Halejing (167 yaks in halejing Mongolian Town, Haiyan County, Haibei Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture); 2. Qilian-Mole (69 yaks in Mole Town, Qilian County, Haibei Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture); 3. Qilian-Yeniugou (42 yaks in Yeniugou Town, Qilian County, Haibei Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture); 4. Qilian-Yanglong (104 yaks in Yanglong Town, Qilian County, Haibei Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture); 5. Qilian-Ebao (28 yaks in Ebao Town, Qilian County, Haibei Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture); 6. Tianjun-Xinyuan (38 yaks in Xinyuan Town, Tianjun County, Haixi Mongolian and Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture); 7. Tianjun-Longmen (100 yaks in Longmen Town, Tianjun County, Haixi Mongolian and Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture); 8. Gande-Ganlong (36 yaks in Ganglong Town, Gande County, Guoluo Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture); 9. Guinan-Taxiu (70 yaks in Taxiu Town, Guinan County, Hainan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture); 10. Henan-Kesheng (73 yaks in Kesheng Town, Henan Mongolian Autonomous Country, Huangnan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture); 11. Ledu-Dala (50 yaks in Dala Town, Ledu District, Haidong City).
This data set comprehensively evaluates the growth performance of yaks grazing in alpine meadow under the current ecological environment through the measurement of weight and body size data in the representative areas of Qinghai pastoral area. The data set can be compared with the growth characteristics of representative populations of Qinghai yaks measured in 1981 and 2008 recorded in 1983 and 2013, and the degradation index of growth performance of yaks grazing in Qinghai pastoral area can be obtained, which is helpful to assess the impact of ecological environment changes on the growth and production performance of grazing livestock.
metadata.instructions: File name: weight and body size data are stored in Excel format, and the file name is "body weights of Yaks in Qinghai 2018. Xlsx".

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific attributes measured to assess the growth performance of yaks in traditional pastoral areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: body weight, body height, body length, chest girth, cannon girth

Quantification.Question: How many yak weight and body measurement samples are included across all locations in a dataset related to yak monitoring in the Qinghai pastoral area?

Interpretation.Question: What does the observed variation in physical traits of yaks across different regions suggest about the influence of regional ecological conditions on traditional grazing practices?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed variation in physical traits of yaks across different regions suggests that regional ecological conditions significantly impact the growth performance of yaks under traditional grazing practices. This inference can be drawn from the comprehensive assessment of yak weight and body measurements in multiple alpine meadow regions, which provides insights into how ecological changes may affect livestock growth and production performance.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on the growth performance of traditional grazing yaks when utilizing data collection methods that measure weight and body size traits across various high-altitude meadow regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing data collection methods that measure weight and body size traits across various high-altitude meadow regions allows for a comprehensive assessment of the growth performance of traditional grazing yaks under the current ecological conditions. This approach can help identify a degradation index of growth performance by comparing the collected data with historical records from 1981 and 2008. Understanding these impacts can aid in evaluating how changes in the ecological environment affect the growth and production performance of grazing livestock.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives in collecting traditional grazing yak weight and body measurement data in high-altitude meadow regions of Qinghai?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives of collecting traditional grazing yak weight and body measurement data in high-altitude meadow regions of Qinghai are to comprehensively evaluate the growth performance of yaks under the current ecological environment and to compare these data with historical measurements from 1981 and 2008. This comparison helps in determining the degradation index of traditional grazing yak growth performance, which is essential for assessing the impact of ecological changes on the growth and production performance of grazing livestock.

Enablement.Question: How do collaborations between research institutes and local veterinary organizations enable the accurate measurement of yak growth traits in high-altitude pastoral regions?
Enablement.Answer: Collaborations between research institutes, such as the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and local veterinary organizations enable accurate measurement of yak growth traits by combining ecological expertise and local knowledge. These partnerships facilitate access to representative yak groups across various regions, ensuring comprehensive data collection on weight and body measurements. This collaborative approach also helps in evaluating the impact of ecological conditions on yak growth performance over time.
